variant.question: In a multi-pilot aircraft, what action might need to be taken by a crew member if another crew member becomes incapacitated in flight?

options.text: Declare an emergency to ensure priority landing at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
Ensure that the upper torso restraint of the affected crew member is loosened, to ensure unrestricted breathing.
Continue as normal without taking any other action as one crew member can still land the aircraft.
Carry out a steep descent in the event of sinus or ear pain.

variant.question: Spatial disorientation is

options.text: the mistaken perception of one’s position and motion relative to the Earth.
a slowly developing process and of little concern.
avoided if one flies under Instrument Flight Rules.
a greater threat when flying with reference to the aircraft’s instruments.

variant.question: Which of the following correctly describes the basic functions of the different parts of the auditory system after sound waves enter through the outer ear?

options.text: Sound waves cause the eardrum to vibrate. Ossicles transmit the vibrations to the cochlea, which translates them into electrical impulses. The auditory nerve carries the impulses to the brain.
The eardrum separates the ear canal from the cochlea, where the sound waves are translated into mechanical impulses. These are transmitted via auditory tubes to receptors in the brain.

Travelling through the semi-circular ear canal, sound waves strike the eardrum, causing it to vibrate. The cochlea translates the sound into pressure waves. Cranial nerves carry the waves to the brain.
Sound waves travel via the ear canal to the eardrum. Mechanical vibrations are translated into fluid vibrations in the cochlea. The Eustachian tube connects the auditory system with the brain.

variant.question: Which behaviour is typically found in the resistance phase of the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS)?

options.text: Application of mental coping strategies
Bodily recuperation.
Relaxed actions.
Fight or flight.

variant.question: Which behaviour is typically found in the resistance phase of the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS)?

options.text: Fight or flight.
Relaxed actions.
Application of mental coping strategies.
Bodily recuperation.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about insidious incapacitation is correct?

options.text: It is the most dangerous form of incapacitation as it may remain undetected by the other pilot(s) in a multicrew cockpit.
Frequent medical screening can reduce the hazard caused by insidious incapacitation as most of the medical causes can be detected before flight safety is affected.
During an insidious incapacitation event in a multicrew aircraft, the affected pilot should be allowed to continue operating during the less demanding phases of flight.
Regular training of insidious incapacitation drills in a flight simulator is ineffective as this type of incapacitation is subtle.

variant.question: With which risk is skill based behaviour associated?

options.text: Action Slip
Deviation from standard operating procedures
Error of commission
Confirmation bias

variant.question: What characterizes the notion of role?

options.text: The function and behaviour associated with the particular role.
The characteristic behaviour associated with the description of the various roles of a particular status.
The hierarchical position of the function and the associated behaviour.
Only the functions associated with role.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning stress is correct?

options.text: Stress will be evaluated differently depending on whether it improves or reduces performance.
Stress always creates a state of high tension which decreases cognitive and behavioural performance.
Stress is a necessary way of demonstrating ones own work.
Stress is evaluated as a positive mechanism only in connection with precise tasks of the kind encountered in aeronautics.

variant.question: What is meant by presbyacusis?

options.text: Gradual loss of hearing with age.
Gradual onset of long-sightedness with age.
Total loss of hearing in one ear due to use of a headset in the cockpit.
Total loss of hearing in both ears due to disease.

variant.question: What is meant by QFE?

options.text: The atmospheric pressure at the official aerodrome elevation.
The present atmospheric pressure at an aerodrome converted to mean sea level in accordance with the actual conditions.
The atmospheric pressure at the official aerodrome elevation, reduced to mean sea level in standard atmospheric conditions.
The pressure at MSL in standard atmospheric conditions.

elevation.

variant.question: What is meant by presbycusis?

options.text: Gradual loss of hearing with age.
Total loss of hearing in one ear due to use of a headset in the cockpit.
Total loss of hearing in both ears due to disease.
Gradual onset of long-sightedness with age.

variant.question: What is meant by QFF?

options.text: The present atmospheric pressure at an aerodrome converted to mean sea level in accordance with the actual conditions.
The present atmospheric pressure at an aerodrome converted to mean sea level in accordance with the ICAO standard atmosphere.
The pressure at mean sea level in standard atmospheric conditions.
The atmospheric pressure at the official aerodrome elevation.

variant.question: Autokinesis is..

options.text: the apparent movement of a static single light when stared at for a relatively long period of time in the dark.
the phenomenon of spinning lights after the abuse of alcohol.
the automatic adjustment of the crystalline lens to objects situated at different distances.
the change in diameter of the pupil, when looking in the dark.

variant.question: Advection is..

options.text: horizontal motion of air.
the same as convection.
the same as subsidence.
vertical motion of air.

variant.question: What is automation mode awareness?

options.text: Being aware of the active mode(s) and understanding the corresponding actions and responses is necessary for proper use of the automated system.
It refers to what mode of awareness a crew has during automated flight.
Examples of mode awareness include vigilance and situational awareness.
It refers to what mode of awareness a crew has during automated flight. Examples of mode awareness include vigilance and situational awareness.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is true about Anaemic Hypoxia?

options.text: It can be caused by smoking.
It can be caused by decompression.
It can be brought on by fatigue.
It can be brought on by altitude.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about RAIM is true?

options.text: At least six satellites are required to detect and identify a faulty satellite.
At least four satellites are required to detect a faulty satellite.
At least five satellites are required to detect and identify a faulty satellite.
At least six satellites are required to detect a faulty satellite.

variant.question: What is learning?

options.text: gaining knowledge through study and past experience
the capacity of the brain.
the capability of human information process.
the ability of the brain to reason without conscious thought.

variant.question: What is learning?

options.text: The ability to gather knowledge or skill.
The ability to process information.
The ability to gather knowledge or skill and is commonly not related to a change in behaviour.
The ability to gather knowledge and starts at school.

variant.question: The dry atmosphere of the flight deck may cause dehydration, which may lead to a reduction in the ability to pay attention. To prevent this, it is appropriate to..

options.text: drink sufficient non-carbonated liquids.
drink plenty of coffee.
drink tea.
drink cool cola drinks.

variant.question: How should a pilot react, when suffering from chronic stress?

options.text: Attempt to reduce the stress by using a concept which approaches the entire body and improves wellness.
Ignore the particular stressors and increase your physical exercises.
Use moderate administration of tranquillizers before flight.
Always consult a psycho-therapist before the next flight.

variant.question:
Which of the following errors occur at rule-based level?
1) Omission.
2) The application of a poor rule.
3) Attentional capture.
4) The poor application of a good rule.

options.text: Resignation
Complacency
Machismo complex
Invulnerability

variant.question: What is a characteristic of the alarm stage of the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS)?

options.text: The body prepares for action.
The adaptation energy is exhausted.
The body copes with the stressor.
The body can no longer resist the stressor.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning checklist is correct?

options.text: The most important items should be placed at the beginning of a checklist since attention is usually focused here.
All the items of a checklist are equally important; their sequence is of no importance.
The most important items must be placed at the end of checklist, allowing them to be kept near at hand so that they are quickly available for any supplementary check.
The most important items must be placed in the middle of checklist so that they come to be examined once attention is focused but before concentration starts to wane.

variant.question: As a result of automation in cockpits,

options.text: communication and coordination call for an even greater effort on the part of the crew members
it is easier for the captain to monitor the work of the first officer and vice versa
communication and coordination have clearly improved in man-man and man-machine relations
the need for communication between crew members has been decreased

variant.question: In case of in-flight stress, one should:

options.text: use all available resources of the crew.
demonstrate aggressiveness to stimulate the crew.
only trust in oneself; being sure to know the own limits.
always carry out a breathing exercise.

is independent on one’s age and professional role.

is independent of the level of motivation.

variant.question: If you are in conflict with a colleague, which of the following techniques can be effectively used to solve the problem?

options.text: Active listening and meta-communication.
Metacommunication and defence.
Self-justification and active listening.
Defence and self-justification.

variant.question: If you are in conflict with a colleague, which of the following techniques can be effectively used to solve the problem?

options.text: Active listening and metacommunication.
Self-justification and active listening.
Defence and self-justification.

variant.question: What is VOLMET?

options.text: Meteorological information for aircraft in flight.
Volume control meter.
Meteorological station.
A device used for measuring cloud base.

variant.question: What is rhodopsine?

options.text: The crystalline lens.
The retina.
The cones.
The rods.

variant.question: What is SELCAL?

options.text: A system that permits selective calling of individual aircraft over a radiotelephone channel linking a ground station with the aircraft, which is unmonitored by the aircraft crew.
A system in which two-way radiotelephony communication can be established between two aircraft of the same operator.
A system in which two-way radiotelephony communication between more than two stations can take place simultaneously, when they are in the area of jurisdiction of the same ATS unit.
A system provided for direct exchange of information between ATS units.

variant.question: What is SELCAL?

options.text: An air to ground communications system that is not monitored by the aircrew.
An air to air communications system.
A system for exchange of messages between Air Traffic Service Units via the Aeronautical Fixed Telephone Network.
A system which enables multiple stations to transmit simultaneously.

variant.question: What is VFE?

options.text: The maximum speed for a specified flap configuration.
The recommended penetration speed for severe turbulence.
The speed never to be exceeded in flight.
The maximum speed for operation of the landing gear.

variant.question: What is hypovigilance?

options.text: Hypovigilance is a state in which individuals need higher levels of sensory stimulation to stay awake.
Hypovigilance is a state in which individuals need lower levels of sensory stimulation to stay awake.
Hypovigilance is a phase of high vigilance.
Hypovigilance is a phase of increased sensory perception.
